Fig. 1 (a) The geometric of C24N24; (b) Top and side perspectives of optimized geometries of Cu-C24N24. Fig 1 Fig. 2 The Eb and Ecoh of 21 types of metal atoms modified C24N24. Fig 2 Fig. 3 The Ef and Udiss of 17 types of metal atoms modified C24N24. Fig 3 Fig. 4 The ED plots (a) and PDOS (b) of Cu-C24N24. Fig 4 Fig. 5 The temperature and energy variations of Cu-C24N24 catalyst through AIMD simulation under 500 K for 1 ps with a time step of 1 fs. The insets are the top and side perspectives of the final structure. C atom: grey, N atom: blue, Cu atom: rose red. Fig 5 Fig. 6 The calculated phonon dispersion of Cu-C24N24. Hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) is an important chemical. The direct synthesis of H2O2 has been identified as an environmentally friendly process through the two-electron oxygen reduction reaction (2e- ORR) under acidic conditions. Nevertheless, the reliance of this technique on expensive electrocatalysts derived from precious metals significantly impedes its practicality for large-scale industrial application. In our study, based on density functional theory calculations, we prove that Cu-modified C24N24 (Cu-C24N24) single-atom catalyst (SAC) is an efficient electrocatalyst based on non-noble metals for 2e- ORR. The results show that Cu-C24N24, Pd-C24N24, Pt-C24N24, and Rh-C24N24 possess good stability. In addition, the Cu-C24N24 SAC exhibits an ideal OOH* binding energy of 4.26 eV, leading to a notably optimal catalytic activity for 2e- ORR. What is more, the Cu-C24N24 SAC shows a preference for aiding in H2O2 production over the rival 4e- ORR with an overpotential of merely 0.04 V. Given these desirable properties, the Cu-C24N24 SAC emerges as a promising option for facilitating 2e- ORR. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Two-electron oxygen reduction reaction Single-atom catalyst Cu-C24N24 Density functional theory calculations Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) plays a crucial role as an eco-friendly chemical in numerous industrial sectors, including pharmaceuticals, papermaking industry, bleaching, wastewater treatment, fuel cells, and chemical synthesis [1-6]. Currently, industrial production of H2O2 predominantly relies on the anthraquinone oxidation (AO) method [7], presenting two main drawbacks: Firstly, it requires large chemical equipment, resulting in high energy consumption [8]; Secondly, potential dangers exist during transportation and storage [9]. These limitations severely restrict the flexible application of this method. Consequently, creating an uncomplicated, economical, and eco-friendly H2O2 synthesis method holds immense importance. Utilizing the electrochemical oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) to synthesize H2O2 presents a promising method [10,11]. The 2e- ORR pathway offers significant advantages for green chemistry and sustainable H2O2 production. This approach enables direct electrochemical synthesis of H2O2 through 2e- ORR, eliminating the need for complex industrial processes and reducing energy consumption [12]. The pathway allows for on-site, decentralized production, minimizing transportation costs and safety risks associated with H2O2 storage and transport [13]. With proper catalyst design, high selectivity towards H2O2 can be achieved, improving efficiency and reducing waste [14]. The mild reaction conditions of ambient temperature and pressure enhance safety and reduce infrastructure requirements [15]. By addressing multiple aspects of sustainability, the 2e- ORR pathway represents a significant advancement in green chemistry and sustainable H2O2 production. Nonetheless, ORR encompasses two conflicting mechanisms: reducing O2 to H2O2 through the 2e- pathway, and reducing O2 to H2O through the 4e- pathway [16]. From a thermodynamic standpoint, this reaction is inclined to synthesize H2O, posing a significant challenge to synthesizing H2O2 via the 2e- pathway. Generating H2O2 typically necessitates two conditions: Firstly, the reaction barrier from OOH* to H2O2 must be lower than the hydrogenation reaction barrier from OOH* to O*. For 2e- ORR, it is essential that the Gibbs free energy change (ΔG) of the intermediate O* (ΔGO*) exceeds 3.52 eV, which is the basis for judging the catalysts of 2e- ORR [17]. Additionally, the appropriate ΔGOOH* on the catalyst is approximately 4.22 eV, which is used to determine the catalyst's high activity for 2e- ORR [18,19]. However, what is noticeable is that achieving ΔGO* > 3.52 eV is extremely difficult. Therefore, it is necessary to find electrocatalysts that meet the above two conditions and have excellent performance. So far, researchers have explored a large number of electrocatalysts based on noble metals [20-24], metal alloys [25-28], and carbon materials [29-33]. Studies have shown that catalysts with metal-N coordination structures typically exhibit excellent electrocatalytic performance. For instance, Gao et al. [16] methodically analyzed the configuration and 2e- ORR catalytic efficiency of nitrogen-doped graphene-supported transition metal (Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, and Cu) single-atom catalysts (SACs) employing a mix of experimental and theoretical methods. Findings indicated that Co-N4 catalysts can serve as effective and selective in synthesizing H2O2. Their selectivity in producing H2O2 exceeded 90 % at 0.6 V (vs. RHE), even slightly excellent to cutting-edge noble metal-based electrocatalysts under acidic conditions. Moges et al. [34] produced Pd-N4 CO, Pd-S4 NCO, and Pd-N2O2 C SACs and analyzed the 2e- ORR catalytic performance of these three catalysts. Comparative studies demonstrated that the Pd-N4 CO catalyst exhibited excellent 2e- ORR catalytic performance. Pd typically has a d-band center closer to the Fermi level, which can lead to stronger adsorption of high electronegativity donor atoms (N atoms) in Pd-N4 CO and weakly coordinated with the intermediate *OOH. Ren et al. [35] employed first-principles calculations to investigate the active sites, catalytic activity, and selectivity of Au-NX-C catalysts in various N vacancy configurations. Findings indicated that the Au-N4 C configuration showed strong Au-O bonding during O2 adsorption, displaying excellent 2e- ORR catalytic performance. The NX-C support (nitrogen-doped carbon) can modify the electronic structure of Au through electron transfer or ligand effects to enable more efficient production of H2O2. Shen et al. [36] utilized nitrogen-doped carbon-supported Ni catalysts under alkaline environments to directly electrocatalytically produce H2O2. Both experimental and theoretical calculations demonstrated that nitrogen-doped carbon-supported Ni catalysts exhibited over 95 % Faradaic efficiency at stable H2O2 production rates, making them promising catalysts for electrochemical H2O2 synthesis. The selectivity toward H2O2 during ORR is remarkably enhanced by the presence of Ni cluster on Ni-N-C materials. N doping in the carbon support can modify the electronic structure of Ni, potentially leading to a more favorable H2O2 production. Sun et al. [37] produced various M-N-C catalysts (M = Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, C = carbon materials) through experimental methods and investigated their activity and selectivity in H2O2 generation. Electrochemical assessments showed that the Co-N-C catalysts demonstrated superior ORR activity, with H2O2 selectivity reaching as high as 80 %. This highlights the Co-N-C catalyst as an outstanding candidate for H2O2 production within this study. Liu et al. [38] constructed 20 axial coordinated M-N4-R electrocatalysts, where M represented a 3d metal and R represented Cl or Br. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations were utilized to analyze their stability, selectivity, and activity. Research demonstrated that the overpotential of Zn-N4-Br is merely 0.05 V. It is comparable to that of recognized platinum-based catalysts. This suggested that Zn-N4-Br had excellent catalytic properties and is the superior candidate for 2e- ORR electrocatalysis. These studies collectively indicate that catalysts with N coordination, especially N4 coordination, often exhibit superior 2e- ORR electrocatalytic performance. C24N24 is a fullerene material that consists of eight triazine rings linked through CC bonds and containing six porphyrin-like N4 cavities. Its N4 cavities have a larger diameter, allowing for the effective binding of transition metal atoms to form SACs. Because of the significant polarization of metal atoms, these metal atoms modified C24N24 SACs exhibit excellent catalytic activity in reactions. Zhang et al. [39] investigated the behaviors of Ti-modified C24N24 (Ti-C24N24) and V-modified C24N24 (V-C24N24) SACs in catalyzing methane (CH4) oxidation to methanol (CH3OH) by DFT calculations. The results indicated that both Ti-C24N24 and V-C24N24 SACs can be used for catalyzing CH4 oxidation to synthesize CH3OH with good stability. Modak et al. [40] investigated the possible ORR reaction mechanisms of Fe-modified C24N24, Co-modified C24N24, and Ni-modified C24N24 (Fe-C24N24, Co-C24N24, and Ni-C24N24) SACs through DFT calculations. The results indicated that all three SACs can catalyze ORR through a more efficient four-electron reduction pathway. Shakerzadeh et al. [41] used dispersion-corrected DFT calculation methods to study the reaction mechanism of CO and O2 molecules on Fe-C24N24 SAC. The results showed that the TER mechanism is the most advantageous among the investigated mechanisms for the oxidation of CO, with a reaction barrier of only 0.35 eV, indicating that Fe-C24N24 is an excellent CO oxidation catalyst. Mousavian et al. [42] studied the reaction process of CH4 directly oxidizing to CH3OH on Fe-C24N24, Co-C24N24, and Ni-C24N24 fullerene by DFT calculations. The results showed the Ni-C24N24 SAC's catalytic performance in CH4 oxidation is more excellent to that of Fe-C24N24 and Co-C24N24, with a reaction barrier of only 0.5 eV. All of the above studies demonstrate that the unique N4 structure of C24N24 can combine with metal atoms to form SACs with excellent catalytic performance. However, there are presently no studies reporting on the electrocatalytic synthesis of H2O2 utilizing C24N24 SACs. Different metal atoms affect the d-band center uniquely, leading to variations in the catalytic performance for H2O2 production. In this study, according to the d-band center theory, considering ten 3d transition metals (TMs) (i. e., Sc, Ti, V, Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Zn), nine 4d TMs (i. e., Y, Zr, Nb, Mo, Ru, Rh, Pd, Ag, Cd), and two high-performance noble metal catalysts (Pt and Au), we constructed 21 types of SACs by adding a transition metal element M (where M represents a transition metal atom) at the N4 sites of C24N24, and investigated their catalytic performance in producing H2O2 via 2e- ORR. DFT calculations demonstrated that Cu-C24N24 is a superior inexpensive electrocatalyst to produce H2O2, characterized by relatively low overpotential (η) (0.04 V). Electronic configuration studies more effectively showed the genesis of the 2e- selectivity and high activity of Cu-C24N24 SAC for 2e- ORR. Our research offers insights for the design of high-efficiency 2e- ORR electrocatalysts. 2 Computational methods The calculations were conducted using the Dmol3 DFT code within the Materials Studio software [43], with detailed calculation parameters provided in Table 1 . In this study, 21 types of SAC models were constructed by anchoring 21 types of metal atoms (Sc, Ti, V, Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Zn, Y, Zr, Nb, Mo, Ru, Rh, Pd, Ag, Cd, Pt, and Au) onto C24N24. The ΔG for each step was determined using the hydrogen electrode (CHE) model [44,45]. Within this model, ΔG was computed based on the provide Eq. (1): (1) Δ G = Δ E + Δ E ZPE − T Δ S + nU + Δ G pH Here, ΔE represents the total electronic energy difference obtained directly using DFT calculations, ΔEZPE represents the zero-point energy difference, T which is 298.15 K, is the temperature, ΔS is the entropy difference, n denotes the transferred electrons number, U denotes the electrode potential applied during the reaction, ΔGpH denotes the concentration correction on the free energy of H + ions: Δ G pH = 2.303 × k B T × pH . In this work, the pH value is established to zero. Within the reaction steps, the potential determining step (PDS) is identified by its maximum ΔG value and the minimal stepwise drop, enabling the computation of the corresponding theoretical limiting potential (UL) using the formula (2): (2) U L = − Δ G PDS / e Where ΔGPDS represents ΔG in the PDS in ORR. What needs to pay attention to is that O2’s free energy is indirectly obtained by considering the ΔG of the reaction 2 H 2 + O 2 → 2 H 2 O . Additionally, the Gibbs free energy of intermediates O* and OOH* in the ORR is obtained as follows: (3) Δ G O * = G O * − G * − ( G H 2 O − G H 2 ) (4) Δ G OOH * = G OOH * − G * − ( 2 G H 2 O − 3 / 2 G H 2 ) 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic structure and stability of 21 types of metal atoms modified C24N24 3.1.1 Electronic structure analysis Firstly, we investigated the geometric and electronic configuration of C24N24. Fig. 1 shows the optimized structure of C24N24 and Cu-C24N24. C24N24 consists of six N4 cavities resembling porphyrin, with a total of 24 CC bonds. CC bonds measure 1.55 Å in length, and the lengths of CN bonds are 1.34 Å. Each cavity can serve as an anchoring point for adsorbing foreign metal atom [46]. Top and side perspectives of the geometrically optimized configurations of C24N24 modified with 21 types of metal atoms are displayed in Fig. 1 and Figure S1. Electrocatalysis requires catalysts with strong stability to resist electrochemical attack. At first, we investigated the stability of C24N24 modified with 21 types of metal atoms through binding energy (Eb) analysis (Table S1 and Fig. 2 ). Eb is characterized as E b = E M @ subs trate − E isol ate − M − E subs trate . EM@substrate, Eisolate − M, and Esubstrate represent the energy of the metal-modified C24N24, isolated metal atoms, and defective C24N24, respectively. A negative Eb indicates a robust connection between the metal and the substrate. Additionally, we calculated the cohesive energy (Ecoh) and compared it with Eb, where E coh = E bulk − M − E isol ate − M , with Ebulk − M being the bulk metal's energy and Eisolate − M being the metal's energy in a solitary environment (Table S1 and Fig. 2). There are 17 types of metal atoms (Sc, Ti, V, Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Zn, Y, Zr, Nb, Rh, Pd, Cd, Pt) whose Eb is more negative than Ecoh, indicating their ability to effectively inhibit aggregation. Therefore, these 17 types of metal atoms are stable on C24N24. In addition, to more deeply demonstrate the stability of the modified metal atoms, the dissolution potential (Udiss) for 17 types of metal atoms modified C24N24 were computed based on a formula U diss = U ∘ diss − E f / e N e . U°diss(M), Ne, and Ef are the dissolution potential of the bulk metal atom, the electron counts in dissolution, and the formation energy, respectively. E f = E M @ subs trate − E bulk − M − E subs trate , where EM@substrate, Ebulk − M, and Esubstrate denote the energy of the metal-modified C24N24, bulk metal atoms, and defective C24N24. Fundamentally, a larger value of Udiss is essential for a catalyst to withstand dissolution in electrochemical scenarios for 2e- ORR [17]. However, due to potential discrepancies between the computed and actual metal Udiss values, and differences in electron transfer between the catalyst and the bulk material during dissolution, we used Udiss > 0 V as a criterion to avoid underestimating candidate materials. Based on Ef and Udiss, we categorized these models into four types corresponding to regions Ⅰ (Ef 〈 0 eV, Udiss 〉 0 V), Ⅱ (Ef > 0 eV, Udiss > 0 V), Ⅲ (Ef < 0 eV, Udiss < 0 V), and Ⅳ (Ef > 0 eV, Udiss < 0 V) (Fig. 3 ). It can be observed that only Cu, Rh, Pd, and Pt are located in region Ⅰ, indicating that C24N24 modified with these four metal atoms exhibit good thermodynamic stabilities (Ef < 0) and effectively inhibit the dissolution of metal atoms, demonstrating strong electrochemical stabilities (Udiss > 0). Therefore, in the subsequent section, we will only discuss the selectivity of these four catalysts for 2e- ORR. To further investigate the stabilities of the catalysts, electron density (ED) and partial density of states (PDOS) analysis were conducted for Cu-C24N24 and C24N24 modified with Rh, Pd, and Pt (Rh-C24N24, Pd-C24N24, and Pt-C24N24), as shown in Figs. 4 and S2-S4. From the ED plot in Fig. 4(a), it can be observed that the electron clouds of Cu overlap with the N atoms, forming strong covalent bonds. Additionally, the PDOS results in Fig. 4(b) reveal that the Cu-3d orbitals and the N-2p orbitals overlap near the Fermi level, with significant overlaps occurring in the ranges of −22.5 to −16.9 eV, −15.1 to −12.7 eV, and −11.8 to 2.0 eV. This indicates a strong interaction between Cu and C24N24. These analyses reaffirm the stability of Cu atoms on C24N24. The situations for Rh, Pd, and Pt atoms on C24N24 are generally consistent with that of Cu (Figure S2-S4). 3.1.2 Thermodynamic and kinetic analysis To more deeply demonstrate the stabilities of the catalysts from the perspectives of thermodynamics and kinetics, ab initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) simulations (as shown in Figs. 5 and S5) and phonon dispersion calculations (Figs. 6 and S6) were conducted for Cu-C24N24, Rh-C24N24, Pd-C24N24, and Pt-C24N24. The results of the simulations in Figs. 5 and S5 indicate that at 500 K for a simulation time of 1 ps with a step size of 1 fs, the geometric configurations of Cu-C24N24, Rh-C24N24, Pd -C24N24, and Pt-C24N24 remained effectively stable, with narrow ranges of temperature and energy vibrations. This suggests that these four catalysts exhibit high thermodynamic stability during the reaction process [47]. Furthermore, in the phonon dispersion spectra shown in Figs. 6 and S6, no imaginary frequencies were observed, indicating its excellent kinetic stability [48]. Thus, the stability of the catalysts was deeply confirmed from perspectives of thermodynamics and kinetics. 3.2 Catalytic performance of Cu, Pd, Pt, and Rh modified C24N24 3.2.1 Catalytic selectivity for 2e- ORR It is well known that 4e- ORR is the primary competing process for 2e- ORR. In each of these pathways, O2 initially combine with H +/e −, resulting in the formation of the OOH* intermediate. This is subsequently followed by a reaction with an additional H +/e − pair, leading to either: a) OOH * + H + / e − → H 2 O 2 (2e- ORR pathway) or b) OOH * + H + / e − → O * + H 2 O (4e- ORR pathway) [49]. OOH* serves as shared intermediate for both ORR pathways, with the end products depending on the cleavage of the OO bond within OOH* [50,51]. From a thermodynamic perspective, to promote the formation of H2O2 rather than H2O and O*, it is imperative that the activation barrier associated with 2e- ORR process be lower than that of the 4e- ORR process. Therefore, the ΔGO* must exceed 3.52 eV, which is the selection criterion for 2e- ORR [52]. In Fig. 7 , ΔGO* is calculated, and it can be observed that among the four catalysts considered, ΔGO* for Rh-C24N24 is < 3.52 eV, suggesting its poor selectivity for generating H2O2. In contrast, the remaining three catalysts, namely Cu-C24N24, Pd-C24N24, and Pt-C24N24, all satisfy the selection standard (ΔGO* > 3.52 eV). Therefore, these three catalysts were selected for further investigation. 3.2.2 Catalytic activity for 2e- ORR To ensure efficient 2e- ORR catalysis, electrocatalysts need to demonstrate both significant stability and selectivity, along with robust catalytic activity. The catalytic activity of both 2e- ORR and 4e- ORR processes are greatly influenced by the OOH* intermediate. Fig. 8 illustrates Gibbs free energy diagrams for 2e- ORR and 4e- ORR for Cu-C24N24, Pd-C24N24, and Pt-C24N24 at U equals 0 V. As can be seen from Fig. 8, these three catalysts all facilitate the formation of H2O2. The inherent performance of electrocatalysts is theoretically measurable through the use of UL or η [44]. Within the reaction mechanism, UL can be calculated using the formula U L = − Δ G PDS / e . The η represents the deviation between UL and the equilibrium potential of 2e- ORR. For electroreduction of O2 to H2O2, the total change in Gibbs free energy is going to be 1.40 eV, so the ideal situation is that the ΔG at each step is 0.70 eV. An ideal catalyst for the electrochemical reduction of O2 to H2O2 should exhibit not only high stability and selectivity but also demonstrate minimal η or a substantial UL approaching the equilibrium potential (0.70 V vs. SHE). Based on the Gibbs free energy diagrams (Fig. 8), we calculated UL for Cu-C24N24, Pd-C24N24, and Pt-C24N24, resulting in values of 0.66 V, −0.06 V, and −0.08 V, respectively. In addition, η values for Cu-C24N24, Pd-C24N24, and Pt-C24N24 are 0.04 V, 0.76 V, and 0.78 V, respectively. Among them, Cu-C24N24 exhibits the smallest η, only 0.04 V, indicating favourable catalytic activity for 2e- ORR process. In addition, we compared it with other catalysts and found that the η of Cu-C24N24 is less than that of other catalysts (shown in Table 2 ), which indicating excellent catalytic activity for 2e- ORR. The superior catalytic activity of the catalyst is attributable to its moderate interaction with OOH*. The ΔGOOH* value provides insight into this binding strength. Typically, high catalytic activity is a consequence of the catalyst's moderate binding strength with the OOH* intermediate. A higher ΔGOOH* indicates a weaker bond between the catalyst and OOH*, while a lower ΔGOOH* suggests less favorable conditions for the desorption of H2O2 [20]. Utilizing H2O and H2 as references, the ideal adsorption free energy for OOH* is 4.22 eV [18,56]. The values of ΔGOOH* for Cu-C24N24, Pd-C24N24, and Pt-C24N24 catalysts were further calculated in Table 3 . The results indicate that the values of ΔGOOH* for Cu-C24N24, Pd-C24N24, and Pt-C24N24 are 4.26 eV, 4.98 eV, and 5.00 eV, respectively. The ΔGOOH* value for Cu-C24N24 is closest the optimal value of 4.22 eV, which explains why this catalyst exhibits the best catalytic performance. 3.2.3 Catalytic mechanism of Cu modified C24N24 in generating H2O2 from O2 In the case of ORR for H2O2 generation, the free energy change analysis above indicates that Cu-C24N24 demonstrates notable catalytic activity and selectivity. To further elucidate the origin of the catalytic performance, we calculated the d-band center of Cu, Pd, and Pt. According to the d-band center theory [57,58], the interaction strength between a metal atom and an adsorbate is primarily determined by the proximity of the metal's d-state main peak to the Fermi level. Analysis of the PDOS plots presented in Fig. 9 reveals that the main peaks of the Cu-d, Pd-d, and Pt-d states are located at −5.52 eV, −6.07 eV, and −6.35 eV, respectively. The findings indicate that Cu-d state is closest to the Fermi level (set to zero in Fig. 9) among the three atoms (Cu, Pd and Pt). This proximity suggests Cu has a strong interaction with N, which results in a weaker interaction with OOH*, and also makes the cleavage of the OO bond more difficult. Consequently, this facilitates the favorable formation of H2O2. In addition, the initial bond length of O–O was 1.345 Å, slightly increased to 1.429 Å (Figure S7) in the OOH* structure, demonstrating that O–O bond cleavage does not occur in O2 + H + +e − → OOH. These results indicate that the Cu moderately activates the O–O bond, which promotes the subsequent hydrogenation of OOH*to yield the final H2O2 product, in agreement with the previously obtained research results. For an in-depth insight into how Cu-C24N24 catalyzes the generation of H2O2 from O2, we analyzed the activation process of O2 molecules using molecular orbital theory [54]. Spin-polarized PDOS was utilized to study the interaction of Cu atoms and O atoms in the O2* and OOH* systems, as shown in Fig. 10 . When O2 molecules are adsorbed onto Cu-C24N24 catalysts in a spin-triplet state, the π* and π orbitals of O2 form bonds with Cu-3d orbitals. The vacant Cu-3d orbitals receive electrons from O2’s bonding orbitals, and the occupied Cu-3d orbitals transfer electrons back to O2’s 2π anti-bonding orbitals as the spin-down π* orbitals’ peak descend beyond the Fermi level. The activation of O2 through a process of electron transfer and feedback leads to the reordering of O2 bonds [59]. When O2 molecules are hydrogenated to form OOH*, the OO bond in OOH* undergoes moderate activation on account of the overlap between the Cu-3d orbitals and the O2–2p orbitals. The overlap suggests that the ORR on Cu-C24N24 is inclined to follow 2e- pathway. 4 Conclusion This paper constructs 21 types of metal-modified C24N24 single-atom electrocatalysts and investigates their potential applications in electrocatalytic conversion of O2 to H2O2 using first-principles calculations. Firstly, the stability of SACs was studied, and the results indicate that only Cu-C24N24, Rh-C24N24, Pd-C24N24, and Pt-C24N24 are expected to be stable single-atom electrocatalysts. Then, the catalytic selectivity of these four catalysts was investigated, revealing that Cu-C24N24, Pd-C24N24, and Pt-C24N24 single-atom electrocatalysts exhibit good selectivity for generating H2O2 via 2e- ORR pathway. In addition, the catalytic activity of these three SACs was examined, with results showing that Cu-C24N24 exhibits the favourable 2e- ORR electrocatalytic performance, with an overpotential of merely 0.04 V, making it a promising low-cost and efficient electrochemical 2e- ORR single-atom electrocatalyst. Finally, the strong interaction between Cu and N results in a weaker interaction with OOH* and reduced O—O bond cleavage, thereby increasing the selectivity of H2O2 production. This study offers significant insights that could greatly advance the development and identification of robust, high-performance SACs for the direct synthesis of H2O2. While numerous theoretical calculations have been achieved, the experimental synthesis of C24N24 still faces considerable challenges, posing difficulties for corresponding experimental research. However, we are optimistic that future breakthroughs in C24N24 preparation technology will enable the verification of our current theoretical findings. coredata.dc:description: Hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) is an important chemical. The direct synthesis of H2O2 has been identified as an environmentally friendly process through the two-electron oxygen reduction reaction (2e- ORR) under acidic conditions. Nevertheless, the reliance of this technique on expensive electrocatalysts derived from precious metals significantly impedes its practicality for large-scale industrial application. In our study, based on density functional theory calculations, we prove that Cu-modified C24N24 (Cu-C24N24) single-atom catalyst (SAC) is an efficient electrocatalyst based on non-noble metals for 2e- ORR. The results show that Cu-C24N24, Pd-C24N24, Pt-C24N24, and Rh-C24N24 possess good stability. In addition, the Cu-C24N24 SAC exhibits an ideal OOH* binding energy of 4.26 eV, leading to a notably optimal catalytic activity for 2e- ORR. What is more, the Cu-C24N24 SAC shows a preference for aiding in H2O2 production over the rival 4e- ORR with an overpotential of merely 0.04 V. Given these desirable properties, the Cu-C24N24 SAC emerges as a promising option for facilitating 2e- ORR.
